item.title: Labour Budget Squeezing Middle-Class Workers, BOE Report Finds
item.description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves’ decision to push up taxes for employers and increase the minimum wage is squeezing pay for middle earners, moving work overseas and inflating food prices.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: A waiter serves water at a restaurant in the Soho district of central London, UK, on Wednesday, June 18, 2025. UK employment plunged by the most in five years and wage growth slowed more than forecast, in the clearest sign yet that Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves’ budget was fueling a deterioration in the British jobs market.

item.title: IMF Chief Says Now Is Great Time to Boost Global Role of Euro
item.description: International Monetary Fund Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva sees a chance to strengthen the euro’s wider role.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze, Michal Kubala

media:content.media:description: Kristalina Georgieva, managing director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), at a news conference during the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank Spring meetings at the IMF headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, April 25, 2025. The International Monetary Fund sharply lowered its forecasts for world growth for this year and next, warning the outlook could deteriorate further as US President Donald Trump's tariffs spark a global trade war.

item.title: IMF Sounds Stagnation Alarm on Euro-Zone Economic Growth
item.description: Europe risks drifting into stagnation without urgent action to tackle slowing growth, weak investment and rising geopolitical threats, the International Monetary Fund warned.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

item.title: BOE Holds Rates and Monitors ‘Deeply Concerning’ Mid-East Events
item.description: The Bank of England held interest rates at 4.25% in a more divided vote than expected as policymakers weighed up the UK’s softening jobs market and weak growth against a backdrop of mounting geopolitical tensions.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees

item.title: SNB Policy Setup Means Big FX Interventions Unlikely, UBS Says
item.description: Large-scale interventions in the franc by the Swiss National Bank are unlikely even though the currency’s strength pushed interest rates to zero, according to economists at UBS.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Swiss franc banknotes.

item.title: Russian Minister Warns of Recession as Officials Spar on Economy
item.description: President Vladimir Putin’s top economic officials openly argued over the state of Russia’s economy during a session at a flagship forum, with one government minister issuing his starkest warning yet that the country may be teetering on the edge of a recession.
item.dc:creator: Greg Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Anton Siluanov at the Saint Petersburg International Economic Forum in Saint Petersburg on June 19.

item.title: Eurogroup Chief Search Kicks Off With Donohoe in Prime Position
item.description: The Eurogroup is about to kick off its search for a new president, with Paschal Donohoe seen on track to win a third term, a feat that would make the Irishman the second-longest-serving chair of the euro zone’s finance-chief meetings.
item.dc:creator: Viktoria Dendrinou, Daniel Basteiro, Kamil Kowalcze, Michal Kubala

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe, president of Eurogroup, during a news conference following a Eurogroup meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on Monday, May 12, 2025. With the euro charting a course for its best year in two decades and asset managers like Amundi SA flipping from bear to bull, Europe's currency is undergoing a resurgence that's rarely been seen at any point since its creation in 1999. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Three Rate Cuts in 24 Hours Show Europe’s Tariff Challenges
item.description: Three interest-rate cuts in just over 24 hours by central banks in Europe highlighted a shift as monetary officials seek to manage the fallout from Donald Trump’s unpredictable trade policies.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss, Ott Ummelas

item.title: India May Cut Oil Product Exports If Strait of Hormuz Is Blocked
item.description: India is preparing to source crude oil from outside the Persian Gulf and cut its own refined-product exports should the Strait of Hormuz be blocked to ship traffic, Oil Minister Hardeep Puri said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Rakesh Sharma

media:content.media:description: An Iranian oil tanker prepares to transport crude oil from Kharq Island to India.

item.title: Turkey Holds Rates, Opens Door to Cuts If Outlook Allows
item.description: Turkey’s central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged, while signaling that it may cut if the downswing in inflation continues and geopolitical risks ease.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman, Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: Fatih Karahan, governor of Turkey's central bank, at his office in Istanbul, Turkey, on Thursday, July 11, 2024. "Any actions we take on policy rates should be calibrated so as to hit the inflation target in 2025 and beyond," Karahan told Bloomberg in the first sitdown interview he's given since being appointed more than five months ago. Photographer: David Lombeida/Bloomberg

item.title: SNB Introduces Stealth Negative Rate to Protect Money Market
item.description: The Swiss National Bank may have cut its interest rate to zero, but the way it penalizes banks’ excess reserve holdings means lenders will face negative rates if they park too much cash at the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Martin Schlegel, president of the Swiss National Bank (SNB), during the bank's rate announcement news conference in Zurich, Switzerland, on Thursday, June 19, 2025. The Swiss National Bank cut its interest rate to zero, seeking to deter investors from pushing up the franc after the currency’s strength caused consumer prices to drop for the first time in four years. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: UK to Invest £725 Billion in Infrastructure Over Next 10 Years
item.description: The UK government outlined plans to spend at least £725 billion ($974 billion) on the country’s creaking infrastructure over the next 10 years, as part of Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s push to use investment to lift economic growth and win back support from the electorate.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: A view of the River Thames from Gravesend looking west towards London, at the location of the proposed Lower Thames Crossing between Kent and Sussex. A Government decision on whether to go ahead with a new 14.3-mile long road crossing is due to be announced on Friday. Work on the £9 billion project has been ongoing since 2009, and more than £800 million of taxpayers' money has been spent on planning. Picture date: Friday October 4, 2024. (Photo by Jordan Pettitt/PA Images via Getty Images)

item.title: Fed Bides Its Time to Find Out Who Will Pay Tariffs
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at the Fed’s reluctance to cut rates. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: Swiss Officials Steer Economy Through Trump’s Tariff Turmoil
item.description: If you’re looking for an example of the turmoil and unintended consequences that trade war threats cause, consider the case of Switzerland.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

item.title: SNB Cuts Rate to Zero and Hints at More to Stop Franc Inflows
item.description: The Swiss National Bank cut its interest rate to zero and signaled it’s ready to go further if necessary as it seeks to deter investors from pushing up the franc.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Martin Schlegel, left, and SNB Board Member Petra Tschudin, at a news conference in Zurich, on June 19. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: Taiwan Holds Key Rate as It Weighs Tariffs, Currency Gains
item.description: Taiwan held its benchmark interest rate for the fifth straight quarter as it considers worries about the impact of possible US tariffs on the economy, inflation and currency gains.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Chien-Hua Wan, Betty Hou

media:content.media:description: Taiwan Central Bank headquarters building in Taipei.

item.title: Norway Unexpectedly Cuts Key Rate, Ending Outlier Status
item.description: Norway’s central bank surprised with its first post-pandemic reduction of borrowing costs, with officials signaling inflation has been sufficiently tamed to ease constriction even more this year. The krone slid.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas

media:content.media:description: Ida Wolden Bache Photographer: Naina Helén Jåma/Bloomberg

item.title: US Focus on Auto Trade Gap Is Sticking Point for Japan Deal
item.description: A strong US focus on its auto trade deficit with Japan is a key factor keeping the two nations from reaching a deal, according to a Japanese opposition party leader who met with Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba to discuss the tariff negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Akemi Terukina, Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Vehicles bound for shipment at a port in Yokohama, Japan. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Villeroy Says If Policy Needs to Change, Loosening More Likely
item.description: The European Central Bank is more likely to further loosen policy if it makes a move in the coming months, as it seeks to remain agile after returning inflation to target, Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau said.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Francois Villeroy de Galhau, governor of the Bank of France, at the Frankfurt European Banking Congress (FEBC) in Frankfurt, Germany, on Friday, Nov. 22, 2024. Addressing the congress European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said the region’s inaction has cost it valuable time since she appeared at that same event in 2023 with much the same message. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Philippines Signals More Easing on Growth Risk, Tame Inflation
item.description: The Philippine central bank cut its key interest rate for a second time this year and signaled there’s scope for further easing with inflation likely to remain modest and economic growth at risk from global uncertainties.
item.dc:creator: Neil Jerome Morales, Ditas B Lopez

media:content.media:description: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas headquarters complex in Manila. Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan Ruling Party Makes Election Pledge of 50% Pay Rise by 2040
item.description: Japan’s ruling party said it aims to ensure workers secure a cumulative 50% pay increase by 2040 with the economy expanding to a value of ¥1 quadrillion ($6.9 trillion) as it unveiled its platform ahead of a national election next month.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians cross a road in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, Aug. 2, 2024. Conditions in Japan’s labor market stayed tight in June, a development likely to keep sustained upward pressure on wages as companies compete to hire and retain workers.

item.title: Namibia Weighs Incentives to Kickstart Total’s Offshore Oil Plan
item.description: Namibia will offer financial incentives to help kick-start the development of oil fields managed by a group led by TotalEnergies SE, according to a special adviser in the presidency.
item.dc:creator: Kaula Nhongo, Paul Burkhardt

media:content.media:description: The TotalEnergies headquarter office in Paris. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

item.title: Gillian Tett on Complex Derivatives and the Fifth Stage of Capitalism
item.description: After the GFC, there was a lot of angst over the fact that so much effort and brainpower went into designing complex derivatives, and other financial instruments. Not only was this seen as wasteful, the complexity was deemed to be the heart of the crisis, and therefore bad. But all these years later, looking back, how bad is financial complexity really? What do things look like from the perspective of 2025. On this episode we’re joined by Gillian Tett, a columnist at the Financial Times, and als
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: ECB’s Lagarde Says More Regional Trade Can Offset Global Losses
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said greater trade in the region could help compensate for losses suffered as a result of global fragmentation.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: IMF Says Zimbabwe’s Economy Has Made ‘Significant Progress’
item.description: The International Monetary Fund said Zimbabwe’s economic reforms have made “significant progress,” but the nation still has more work to do before earning an IMF staff-monitored program.
item.dc:creator: Godfrey Marawanyika, Ray Ndlovu

media:content.media:description: Shoppers browse grocery stores in the central business district of Harare, Zimbabwe, on Monday, Feb. 12, 2024. Zimbabwe may back its currency with gold in an effort to end exchange-rate instability, Finance Minister Mthuli Ncube said.

item.title: South Korea Plans $22 Billion Extra Budget as Tariffs Hit Growth
item.description: South Korea unveiled an extra budget worth billions of dollars, in a bid to support an economy struggling with sluggish consumption and mounting trade headwinds from Donald Trump’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: South Korean president Lee Jae-myung during his inauguration ceremony.

item.title: Australia’s Beef Industry Can Wait Out Trump Tariffs, Envoy Says
item.description: Australia should maintain its cautious approach to the Trump administration’s “reciprocal” tariffs, despite the potential impact on the beef industry which makes up a major part of the nation’s agricultural exports to the US, according to a government trade envoy.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: Cattle at a farm in Gunnedah, New South Wales, Australia.

item.title: Swiss Exports to US Collapse as Shippers Wait for Tariff Deal
item.description: Swiss exports to the US plunged for a second month as cross-border shippers wait for a trade deal to cushion tariffs proposed by President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

item.title: Japan to Propose Trimming Super-Long Bond Issuance From July
item.description: Japan’s finance ministry is considering trimming its issuance of super-long bonds starting in July, according to a draft of a revised bond issuance plan seen by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Takashi Umekawa, Erica Yokoyama
